turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I'll have the same.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: What was that?  I can't order  my eggs without sarcasm?

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Tell me.  When you get to the altar, will you spike the bouquet?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: You know, there's no...

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Ike... Hi, Grandma.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Gram here was going to give me the skinny on why you run from marital bliss.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Oh, my God -- It's Miles Davis.  This is "King of Blue"!  This is the original recording.  Hard to find in good condition.  Where did you find this?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: It was in the attic.  It was jus sitting there gathering dust.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: It's valuable.  Hang onto it.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: No.  You take it.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Hmmm... Figuring out what kind of music I like and then finding me a rare album. You're not trying to soften me up, are you?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: No -- I'm cleaning an attic.  I wouldn't attempt the impossible.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Watch your leg, Dad.  I'm so tired of this.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Why don't you let him sleep it off in the trunk. I'll take you for a ride. Then we'll come back for him.  Keep an eye on him.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Your filter's clogged.  This takes unleaded.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Can you fix it?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: First I have to find some tools.  I need a half and a nine-six-tenth.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Of what?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Wrenches.  My dad's gonna love that one.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Kind of isolated.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Yeah.  It's kind of nice.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: No.  But I think attraction is too often mistaken for rightness. Attraction is very misleading.  And if it's mutual, it's well, terribly distracting.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Yes it is.  And it doesn't mean anything.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Where did you disappear to?

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Missed me bad, huh?

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: I don't know, give me a minute.  Are you all right with this?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Are you all right with this?  You think this is funny?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: I don't and I don't think you should...

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: I'm the only goddamn person in there pulling for you.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: You humiliated me!

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: No, Maggie, I defended you. Humiliating you is what everyone else is doing.  It's the theme of this party.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I had it under control.  Now they feel sorry for me.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Well, they should.  Because they're about to watch you hang yourself again.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: It's fun!  It's high.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Or the sexual habits of locusts?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: That was very interesting research George was doing!

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: What kind of Dead Head gets a temporary tattoo?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I already explained about that.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: And where you ever really going to run the leper colony in Molokai?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Brian told you that?

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Or maybe you just wanted to wear the headdress.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Every one of those times I was being supportive.  Something you won't understand.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Supportive?  You weren't being supportive.  You were being scared. Just like now.  You are the most lost woman I have ever laid eyes on.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Lost!

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: That's right.  You're so lost you don't even know how you like your eggs.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: What!?

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: With the priest, you liked them scrambled.  With the Dead Head, fried. With the bug guy, poached.  Now it's egg whites only, thank you very much.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: That's called changing your mind.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: No, that's called not having a mind of your own.  What are you doing, Maggie? You really want to let that man drag you up Annapuma on your honeymoon?  You don't want to climb Annapuma.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Yes I do!

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: No you don't.  You want a man who will lead you down the beach with his head over your eyes just so you can discover the feel of the sand under your feet. You want a guy who will take you into a cave with a thousand candles just to read you a poem.  You want a man to wake you up at dawn because he's burning to talk to you and he can't wait another minute to find out what you'll say.  Am I right?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: No.  No -- Actually, let's make Ike the pastor.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: I'd rather not.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Come on, it'll give you a great view. It's perfect.  Hey.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: I'm sorry, Bob.  She kissed me back.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I kissed him back.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: About a minute...?

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: A little longer for me.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Okay.  So... what, uh... What just happened?  Just now?  Jus then?  In there?

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: I don't know.  I, uh -- I frankly don't even want to talk about it.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Me, either.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: I love you.  I love you.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I love you, too.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: To who?  Are you asking me?

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Me?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Yes, you!

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Well, you do have the dress.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: And the church.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: And the wedding date.  There's the two of us.  So, you think... maybe... You have to go down the aisle with somebody you love and who love you back.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I'm okay with that.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: So am I.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: So, we'll...

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I've been making friends with your cat.  Is it okay that I'm here?

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: I don't have much choice in the matter now, do I?  But I can't speak for Italics.  Traitor!

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Livid is good.  So what is it, Maggie? You here on business?  I saw your lamps. They're terrific.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: It's something I've always wanted to do.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: You actually could make breaking and entering into a new career.  So, what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I wanted to talk to you about why I run or ride away from things.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Does it matter?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I think so... When I was walking down the aisle?  I was  walking toward somebody who didn't have any idea who I really was.  And it was only half the other person's fault, because I had done everything to convince him that I was exactly what he wanted.  So it was good that I didn't go through with it because it would have been a lie, but you -- you knew the real me.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Yes, I did.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I didn't.  And you being the one at the end of the aisle didn't just fix that.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Used?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: They're mine.  I'm turning in my running shoes to you.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: This is getting serious.

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: You were not.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I was, because if you said "yes" right away, I wouldn't get to say this next part.  And I've been practicing it.  Ready?

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: I'm listening.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: "I guarantee that we'll have tough times.  I guarantee  that at some point one or both oof us will want to get out. But I also guarantee that if I don't ask you to be mine, I'll regret it for the rest of my life. Because I know in my heart -- you're the only one for me".

turns.speaker: IKE
turns.text: Pretty good speech, Maggie.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I borrowed it from this guy I know. So?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: So -- Mag -- you've seen this, huh?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Yes, I've seen it.  And I have to say it's the rudest and most offensive... joke anybody's ever played on me!

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You're a goddess!

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I didn't even need to change this gasket, just put in a little hydraulic fluid.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Stop it.  When you talk like that, I get turned on and it frightens me.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Reporter?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Yup!

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Hold on -- Nobody interviews Maggie in here unless they're getting haircut.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: She's the boss.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Okay, he's on base.  Can we talk about my life now?  -- Ike's going to turn that tattoo stuff into a big deal -- that I was never serious about Gill, blah blah.  He's totally out to get me.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: For what reason?  Some personal satisfaction?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: That's what he says, but if he thinks that I don't realize he's writing another article, then he's an idiot.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: It's probably because you got him fired.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Ya think?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Not that he doesn't deserve to get fired... Look!  Cory's going for second!... Sneaky!

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: There he is.  Snoop Doggy-Dogg.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Over there.  Ten o'clock.  He's talking to our little Dennis.  Dennis will turn into one of those "sources say" things.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: He looks better with that stuff out of his hair.  He's an attractive man.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Good morning to you, too.  You look good.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Thank you.  Do you think I flirt with Cory?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I know.  I think sometimes you just sort of spaz-out with random excess flirtation energy and it just lands on anything male that moves.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: On anything male that moves?  As opposed to anything male that doesn't move?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I'm going to kill myself.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Because you think I'm all like... "Hey man, check me out".

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: No, I don't think you're like, "I'm charming and mysterious in a way that even I don't understand and something about me is crying out for protection from a big man like you".  Very hard to compete with.  Especially to us married women who have lost our mystery.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: But you haven't lost your mystery! You're very mysterious!

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: No.  I'm weird.  Weird and mysterious are two different things.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: But I'm weird.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: No.  You're quirky.  Quirky and weird are two different things.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Peggy, there's distinct possibility that I might be profoundly and irreversibly screwed up.  Despite that, I love you and I can promise that I will no longer flirt with Cory, and I beg your forgiveness.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'm not worried about you and Cory or Cory and me or even that you're irreversibly screwed up.  But, Maggie, you've been like this since we were kids.  And I think now that you are aware of it and that it hurts people's feelings, maybe it's time to move on with your life and commit to someone of your own, like Bob, if he's the one.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I think you're right.  Is there anything I can do to make it up to you?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Something that brings warmth to my heart.  Duckbill platypus.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: It's only funny at Camp Birchwood at three in the morning at a tick hunt. It's not anymore.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You're right.  It's not funny now. Maybe we both grew up.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Thanks.  Will you fix my hair?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Lighten up, wahine.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Lighten up, what?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: This party is for you and Bob.  Get your mind off the reporter.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I haven't seen him in twenty-four hours. It just gives me the creeps a little bit. I'd feel better if I knew where he was.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Would it?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: He's going to be the pastor?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Yep.  I want him to be front and center and to watch everything.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What happened at the luau?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: ... I don't even want to talk about the luau.  What's this?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: It's for the bell.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Grandma!

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: See, this is a mature relationship. She's really found it.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: He's not coming.  Watch.  He's not coming.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: No, no.  I saw eight geese flying in a "V".

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: You and your lucky geese.  You always see geese.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Not eight...

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Let's go.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: No sauntering down the aisle.  Just make time.  Let's just get there.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You okay?  I'm closing.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I'm just finishing up, too.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Want to go to Butch's for a drink or something?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: No, I'm just going to head home.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Wedding.  Wedding.  You just have to get the rest of your ducks in a row.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Thank you.  You still think that he was....

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Quick.  Very quick.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: So I've come to see it as a bonus, really, that we've been able to plan, and pay for, so many weddings.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Not this one.  This one's on me.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: I'm not exactly having fun, either... Steady.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Good boy, Port Hole.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: His name is Skipper, Dad... Steady.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I changed it.  See you later, Mr. Travis.  That guy has a problem... Maggie, you can run everyone's life but your own.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I'm really rooting for this one.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Thank you, Dad.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: Just stop it.  Don't say another word like that.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Maggie, it's just a joke...

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: No.  It's my life.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: A harmless joke.

turns.speaker: MAGGIE
turns.text: No, it's humiliating and you've been doing it since I was a kid.  I don't like it.  Stop.  You may not like having a daughter with problems.  But guess what?  I don't like having a father who's drunk all the time.  I'll eat in my room.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: "What is unusual about Miss Carpenter is that she likes to dress her men up as grooms before she devours them.  She has already disemboweled six in a row by leaving them at the altar."... I can't ready anymore.

turns.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
turns.text: "And her ritual feast continues as she prepares to make a sacrifice out of the seventh fiance.  So all bets are on and we hope that this boomerang bride isn't honeymooning with Las Vegas odds makers because many predict that this girl is out of there before the race... before the rice hits the ground"  Holy moly.

turns.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
turns.text: You tell Maggie.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: No, you tell her.

turns.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
turns.text: No, no.  You're her best friend.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
turns.text: You know, it's just possible that she hasn't read this yet.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
turns.text: Maybe she hasn't read the paper...

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: There's no why, Annie.  I'm just not up for it.  I never said I was.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Is there somebody else?

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You don't love me, is that it?

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: How about ... you're too narcissistic to commit to another human being in a long- term way.

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: That's good.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You take the microwave?

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: What am I going to do with a microwave?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You turn it on, you open it and you stand in front of it for a very long time.

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: So you're angry.  Big deal.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Tell me he's living in squalor. Tell me everything he has is being repossessed, including his filthy, dented mobile home.

turns.speaker: WHEEDLE
turns.text: He's got a houseboat.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I hate boats.

turns.speaker: WHEEDLE
turns.text: It sounds nice.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Boats.  You go out in them. You come back in them.  I hate them.

turns.speaker: WHEEDLE
turns.text: Houseboats don't go anywhere.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Boats.  All anyone talks about is the wind.  Is it up, is it down.  I can't live with a man who only talks about the wind.

turns.speaker: WHEEDLE
turns.text: It's not a boat boat.  It's really a house.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: But it's on the water.

turns.speaker: WHEEDLE
turns.text: It's on the lake right in the middle of Seattle.  It rains nine months of the year in Seattle.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I hope I don't have to pay for that piece of information.

turns.speaker: WHEEDLE
turns.text: No, that's free.  He's an architect.  Used to do big high-profile projects.  He scaled it all back when his wife died.  Now he remodels people's homes.  He works in a small firm, makes a good living.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: The short one with black hair is your cousin Irene --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: -- who's married to --

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Harold, who ran away with his secretary but came back --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: -- because Irene threatened to put the dog to sleep if he didn't --

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: And your brother Tom is a psychology professor and is married to...Betsy --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: -- who is the most competitive woman in the world --

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Your Uncle Milton lost all his money in a Puerto Rican condominium that went belly up, don't mention the IRS or the Federal prison system.  Your mother is Barbara, your father is Cliff --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I hope he doesn't get out his slides.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Am I what they had in mind?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: They're going to love you.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Don't touch them.  I feel terrible sneezing at a time like this.  This is a big moment for me --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: He's allergic to everything, don't worry about it --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: If he eats one tiny piece of a nut --

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: My head swells up like a watermelon and I drop dead.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Is that all right with you?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Today I consider myself the luckiest man on the face of the earth.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: They loved you.  I told you they would love you and they did.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I love you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I love you, Walter.  Did anyone ever call you anything other than Walter?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Even when you were young?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Nope.  Not even when I was young.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You sure you don't want to drive with me?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: How will I get back to Baltimore Saturday?  Oh God, I forgot my present for your stepmother -- I took it inside by accident.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I'll wait.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Don't be silly.  I'll just be ten minutes behind you.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Happy New Year, darling.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Happy New Year.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I was thinking, I have to go up to Boston for the AAP convention and then visit Winston-Hughes about switching over our computers.  Why don't we meet in New York for Valentine's Day weekend?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Walter, I'd love to --

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: We'll stay at the Plaza --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Go for a walk in Central Park --

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Go to the Symphony --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: We will?  The Symphony?  Okay.  I'll take you to the Russian Tea Room for pelmeni.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's delicious, trust me.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Does it have wheat in it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, it's just Becky, she's having trouble with Rich again.  Hold on, Becky, I'm going downstairs.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Miss Scarlett.  In the broom closet.  With the radio.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I gotta go.  I'll see you at work.  Walter, you scared me.  Don't ever do that again.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Becky heard this woman on the radio complaining about this guy she was sure was Rick, which meant he was cheating on her.  She was completely hysterical.  Then it turned out the woman lived in Duluth.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: That doesn't make any sense.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I know.  It makes no sense at all.  Thank God my life is in place.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Couldn't you just do a phone interview?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Not for the kind of place I want to do.  I won't be in Chicago that long.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: When you get back, I'll be gone --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: And then I'll see you in New York --

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Okay, okay.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You go.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Ever since Christmas, you've been different.  Kind of distracted, distant.  But I feel like you're coming back from wherever you were.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I am.  I was just... I just got... I think I got nervous.  It's normal, right? Don't you ever feel nervous about, you know?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: About forever.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, I did.  And you know what I think? I think that it was almost... too perfect.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Don't hate me but I love this pattern.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You couldn't.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I do.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: It's just like my grandmother's china.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Walter.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: It was my mother's.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's so beautiful.  It's just what I would have picked out if I'd had every ring in the world to choose from.  You see what I mean.  There are people who would like a relationship to be full of surprises, but I am not one of them.  Surprises are highly overrated.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Beautiful view, isn't it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Walter, there's something I have to tell you --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't know what to say about it, Walter.  It was a form of temporary insanity.  But I had to tell you about it because --

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: -- it was a betrayal.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yes.  But it wasn't really.  It was just...

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: So what happened?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I told you.  Nothing --

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: At the top of the Empire State Building --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'm not at the top of the Empire State Building.  I'm here.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Not really.  Look, Annie, I love you.  Let's leave that out of it.  I don't want to be someone you're settling for.  I don't want to be someone anyone settles for.  I have a life insurance policy, I'm fully invested in growth stocks, I have a paid subscription to Home Rox Office, I have no sexual diseases, I have been steadily employed in a part of the economy that isn't soft, I have expectation in the way of inherited wealth, I dress nicely, I am a member of the private sector, an independent voter, I don't watch Monday Night Football, the only thing wrong with me is that I am allergic to wheat, strawberries, penicillin, pollen, nuts and wool.  There are plenty of women who see me as the brass ring.  If you don't -- marriage is hard enough without bringing such low expectations into it, isn't it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, Walter.  I don't deserve you.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I think that's what I'm saying.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You okay?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Yes.  Some people will do anything to get out of going to a symphony.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Look!

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: You should write something about this.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: Whatever it is.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: It's not true, but it feels true.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: There's practically a whole book about how that statistic is not true --

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: What was that about up there?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What was what?

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: What's with you?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Nothing's with me.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: "Sleepless in Seattle"?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's what she called him on the show.  Because he can't sleep.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: And now 2,000 women want his number.  The guy could be a crackhead, a psychopath, a flasher, a junkie, a transvestite, a chain-saw murderer, or someone really sick, like Rick.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Actually, he sounded nice.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: Oh? Oh, really? Now we're getting down to it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Not.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: You're a basket case.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: They knew it.  Time, distance, nothing could separate them. Because they knew.  It was right.  It was real.  It was...

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: ... movie.  That's your problem.  You don't want to be in love.  You want to be in love in a movie.  Read it to me.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: "Dear Sleepless and Son..."

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: It sounds like the name of a mattress store --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: "I am not the sort of person who listens to call-in radio shows" --

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: And this woman is a writer! That's what everyone writes at the beginning of letters to strangers.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I know that.  You think I don't know that? "I know that's a dumb way to begin, but it's the only way I can think of to convey what happened to me the other night when I heard the two of you on the radio.  On the other hand, maybe I'm just losing my mind."

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: You are.  You're losing your mind.  What about Walter?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'm going to marry Walter.  I just have to get this out of my system.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I should say something in this about magic.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't know.  I mean, what if I never meet him? What if this man is my destiny and I never meet him?

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: Your destiny can be your doom. Look at me and Rick.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: "I want to meet you..."

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: "On top of the Empire State Building at sunset on Valentine's Day."

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Good.  Perfect.  I'll be in New York with Walter, I can squeeze it in.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: You want to hear about destiny? If my husband hadn't gone on a diet, which caused me to leave him, I would never have been on that flight to Miami, and met Rick, and ended up having sex in the bathroom of a 727 with that nob you slide that says "vacant-occupied, vacant- occupied, vacant-occupied" --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You never told me you left your husband because he went on a diet.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: He lost all the weight... there.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's impossible.  A guy can't --

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: Can too.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: And then you left him? He lost weight there and you left him?

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: Plus he fell in love with a temp.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Listen to this, I love this part --

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: Men never get this movie.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: Do you think at the end of the movie when she's in the wheelchair they can still do it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I always wondered about that too.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: Turn on your radio!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: The kid is on.  You've got me listening to this garbage. Go on, turn it on.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I thought I would look into doing a story about those radio shows.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: You'd probably have to go somewhere to really look into it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Definitely.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: Did you talk to him?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I couldn't do it.  How did I get here?

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: You told a lie and got on a plane.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's not what I mean.  I'm going back over there tomorrow and talk to him.  I am.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: Okay.  Good.  Goodbye.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Becky?

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Is this crazy?

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: No.  That's the weirdest part about it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Thank you.  I love you.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: I love you, too.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: You were standing in the middle of the street?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You know that dream where you're walking down the street naked and everyone is looking at you?

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: I love that dream.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That was nothing compared to this humiliation, nothing.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: But he saw you, right?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: He said hello.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: It's a sign --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's a sign I've watched this movie too many times.  I'm so stupid.  From the minute I listen to that stupid program on the radio, I've been a complete jerk.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: You don't know who she was, Annie --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I saw her.  She looked just like this --

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: This is a photo of hair.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, it's the same woman.  And he was crazy about her.  What is this?  This is from Seattle.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Becky?

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: So I mailed your letter.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: "Dear Annie: Thanks for your letter.  It was great.  We're very excited about meeting you in New York on Valentine's Day and seeing if we are M.F.E.O. Sleepless in Seattle."

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: M.F.E.O.?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Made for each other.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: So he can't write.  Big deal. I mean, verbal ability is a highly overrated thing in a guy, and our pathetic need for it is what gets us into so much trouble.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'm going to run back to Walter's arms, if he's still have me.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: What about the letter?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It doesn't mean anything.  It was written before I went out there.  Before the ho.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: You're going to miss the train.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, I'm not.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: What are your plans in New York?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: We're going to the Rainbow Room and the symphony tomorrow night.

turns.speaker: BECKY
turns.text: I love the symphony.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I hate it.  I'm so happy, Becky.  Finally I feel happy.  This is right. This is real.  Everything else is what happens when you watch too many movies and completely lose sight of what counts.  Please don't tell anyone about what happened.  "Sleepless in Seattle" is history.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I need to know about him because... he's involved with my sister...

turns.speaker: DET. WHEEDLE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: She has a pattern of getting involved with losers... Once she almost ran away with a human cannonball from the circus.

turns.speaker: DET. WHEEDLE
turns.text: Do you want a matrimonial, past wives, any kids--

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, I know that part --

turns.speaker: DET. WHEEDLE
turns.text: So you want a financial, is he a deadbeat, we can do a D&B --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, no, no, it's more like, who is he, does he have a sense of humor, is he nice -- no forget nice, I've got nice --

turns.speaker: DET. WHEEDLE
turns.text: A sense of humor.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'll tell you the truth, I heard this guy on a call-in radio show and I might not marry the person I should marry because I've become obsessed with him.

turns.speaker: DET. WHEEDLE
turns.text: Oh.  Like Glenn Close in that movie.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No.  Not remotely.  I just want to find out about him.

turns.speaker: DET. WHEEDLE
turns.text: You want a tail.  I got a guy in Seattle --

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: Honey, he wasn't right for you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: He wasn't even wrong for you, like <u>cosmically</u> wrong, so don't beat up on yourself for wasting...however long it was.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: Maybe you should see a shrink.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I want my money.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: Go home for the weekend.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's what I'm going to do. I'm going to go home.  I quit.  Laurie, I quit.  I'm going back to Baltimore.  How does a blonde do a high- five?
